work.p: Ideas and phrases from this manuscript are similar to ideas and phrases that appear in the poem eventually titled "Song of Myself." Lines from the manuscript also match lines in another manuscript that may have contributed to the poem eventually titled "Song of Myself." See tex.00031.

Ideas and words from this manuscript are similar to ideas and words that appeared in the preface to the 1855 Leaves of Grass. See, for instance, the line: "the melancholy prudence of the abandonment of such a great being as a man is to the toss and pallor of years of moneymaking with all their scorching days and icy nights and all their stifling deceits and underhanded dodgings, or infinitessimals of parlors, or shameless stuffing while others starve . . " (1855, p. x).

There is a chance this manuscript relates to language in a Whitman-authored review of the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass. The review, titled "Walt Whitman and His Poems" and originally published in the United States Review, includes the sentence: "One of the roughs, large, proud, affectionate, eating, drinking, and breeding, his costume manly and free, his face sunburnt and bearded, his posture strong and erect, his voice bringing hope and prophecy to the generous races of young and old."

notesStmt.note: Edward Grier concludes that this manuscript was likely written before 1855 because of its similarity to several of the notebooks that Whitman wrote from that period (Notebooks and Unpublished Prose Manuscripts [New York: New York University Press, 1984], 6:2110). Ideas in this manuscript are similar to ideas in the first poem in the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass, eventually titled "Song of Myself," and lines and phrases from the manuscript appear in another manuscript that may have contributed to the poem eventually titled "Song of Myself": see "I know many beautiful things." The tone of the statements is also consistent with Whitman's early journalistic and editorial persona.
